PMT  12 Asmall, gas-filled balloon was dropped from a height. The displacement-time graph for the balloon is shown.  2.0  Displacement / m oS     N -) N  = oO  0.00 0.25 0.50 0.75 1.00 1.25 1.50  Time / s  As the displacement of the balloon from its point of release increased, gravitational potential energy was transferred to kinetic energy and thermal energy.  (a) State why the rate of energy transfer was greatest at 1.20 s.  (b) By calculating the change in gravitational potential energy of the balloon between 1.05 s and 1.20 s, show that the average rate at which the gravitational potential energy was transferred during this time interval was about 0.2 W.  mass of balloon and air = 0.004 kg  (Total for Question 12 = 4 marks)  9  Ti

PMT  13 (a) State what is meant by work done.  (b) A car of mass 1.5 x 10  kg is travelling on a country road towards a village at 55 miles per hour. The speed limit in the village is 30 miles per hour.  When the brakes are applied, there is a constant braking force of 3750 N.  Calculate the minimum distance before reaching the village that the driver should apply the brakes to avoid exceeding the speed limit.  55 miles per hour = 24.6 m s!  30 miles per hour = 13.4 ms"!  Minimum distance = ooo ccccccccccccccccccecececceveseeeeteveveeee  (Total for Question 13 = 4 marks)  10  P 449 2 2 A 0 1 0 2 8

15 The photograph shows a praying mantis hanging from a thin twig. Four of the praying mantis s six legs are in contact with the twig. The tension in the legs balances the weight to keep the praying mantis stationary.    Robert Clamp  (a) The diagrams show a simplified model of the situation. For each leg in contact with the twig, the upper section is horizontal and the lower section is at an angle of 30  to the vertical.  lower section  upper section  Side view End view  (1) Calculate the tension in the lower section of each leg in contact with the twig assuming that these tensions are all equal.  mass of praying mantis = 5.4 x 10% kg  P44 9 2 2 A 01 2 2 8  PMT

PMT  (1) A student suggests that the tension 1n each leg in contact with the twig 1s 25% of the weight of the praying mantis. State why this is not correct.  (b) The praying mantis moves around the twig so that it is now standing upright and on top of the twig.  State the difference between the stress in the legs when the praying mantis is beneath the twig and when it is on top of the twig.  (Total for Question 15 = 6 marks)  13  Ti

PMT  17 A passenger is standing in a train.  (a) The train accelerates and he falls backwards.  Direction of travel  Direction of acceleration  Use Newton s first law of motion to explain why he falls backwards.  P44 9 2 2 A 0 1 6 2 8

PMT  *(b) As the train leaves the next station the passenger holds on to a vertical support as the train accelerates. This prevents the passenger falling backwards.  Direction of travel  Direction of acceleration  With reference to Newton s laws of motion, explain why holding on to a vertical support prevents the passenger falling backwards.  (Total for Question 17 = 8 marks)  17  Ti

18 A student investigated the physics of football.  (a) She used the equations of motion to model the behaviour of a ball when kicked at different angles to the horizontal. She predicted the height of the ball when it reached the goal, presuming it was kicked from the same place, with the same initial speed,  each time. The results are shown in the table below. PMT  (b) (4) During a football match the ball is kicked towards the goal, at an angle of 15  to the horizontal, from a distance of 11 m as shown.  goal  Side view  The ball has a diameter of 0.22 m and an initial speed of 26 ms .  By means of a calculation, determine whether or not the ball will pass into the goal. You may ignore the effects of air resistance.  19  Ti
PMT  (11) Aur resistance would cause an additional force on the ball.  Explain the effect this would have on the ball s motion.  (Total for Question 18 = 11 marks)  P 449 2 2 A 0 2 0 2 8

PMT  19 An exhibit in a science museum requires the observer to use a pump to create air bubbles in a column of liquid. The bubbles then rise through the liquid.  (a) (1) Complete the free-body force diagram for a bubble as it rises through the liquid. (3)  *(11) It is observed that larger bubbles reach the top of the column of liquid in less time than smaller bubbles.  By considering the forces acting on a bubble as it rises, explain this observation.  (3)  21  Ti
